p.docType: Implementation of the international drug control treaties

p.docProponent: Australia, Japan and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland: draft resolution
p.docTitle: Promoting international cooperation in responding to new psychoactive substances

preamble.p: Concerned that new psychoactive substances are increasingly being marketed as legal alternatives to internationally controlled drugs and that those substances may pose risks to public health and safety,
Acknowledging the dynamic and fast-paced nature of that market and the increasing role that the Internet plays in the trade of new psychoactive substances,

Deeply concerned about reports of the increased and emerging use of and trade in new psychoactive substances, such as synthetic cannabinoids, 4-methyl-methcathinone (mephedrone), methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV), other cathinones and phenethylamines, that have effects similar to those of internationally controlled drugs,
Concerned about the potential opportunities for transnational organized criminal groups to exploit the market for those substances, at unknown risk to the health of consumers,

content.p: Encourages Member States to monitor emerging trends in the composition, production and distribution of new psychoactive substances, including through the Internet, as well as the increasing use of those substances within their own national borders;

Urges Member States to share that information, in particular with regard to patterns of use and related problems, risks to public health, forensic data and regulation of new psychoactive substances, with other Member States and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime;

Encourages Member States, based on the information on patterns of use and risks to public health of new psychoactive substances, to adopt appropriate measures aimed at reducing demand and risks associated with the use of those substances to minimize risks to public health;

Requests the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime to continue to work with the World Health Organization, pursuant to article 3 of the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961
United Nations, Treaty Series. vol. 520, No. 7515.
as amended by the 1972 Protocol
Ibid., vol. 976, No. 14151.
and article 2 of the Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971,
Ibid., vol. 1019, No. 14956.
towards resuming the review of substances for possible scheduling by the Commission
